thread.section_title: Grammy Awards 2017 Performances, Winners and Red Carpet Dresses | Daily Mail Online
thread.title: Flume wins Grammy award for best Dance/Electronic album
thread.title_full: Flume wins Grammy award for best Dance/Electronic album | Daily Mail Online

author: Alex Michael For Daily Mail Australia
title: Flume wins Grammy award for best Dance/Electronic album
text:
Australian DJ Harley Streten, known professionally as Flume, has won his first ever Grammy award .
The 25-year-old shocked himself and the world as he graciously accepted America's most sought-after music prize.
The stunned musician revealed the win was 'insane,' but made sure to tell the audience he was proud to be representing Australia while on stage accepting the award.
Scroll Down For Video
'Insane': Australian DJ Flume has shocked the music world by winning a Grammy for best Dance/Electronic album, saying the win was 'insane'
The young DJ beat out several Electronic music veterans to nab the coveted prize.
The Sydney-born star's moody dance record Skin bested releases from Tycho, Jean-Michael Jarre, Underworld and Louie Vega to nab the award.
The popular album topped both the Australian and New Zealand overall charts upon its release in May last year, reaching the top 10 in the USA.
Lead single Never Be Like You achieved Platinum sales in seven countries, and was also nominated for the Best Dance Recording category earlier in the night, losing out to DJ duo The Chainsmokers.
The competition: The 25-year-old's moody dance record Skin bested releases from Tycho, Jean-Michael Jarre, Underworld and Louie Vega to nab the award
1 from 2: Lead single Never Be Like You was also nominated for the Best Dance Recording category earlier in the night, losing out to DJ duo The Chainsmokers
Flume joins a surprisingly exclusive list of Australian artists who have won Grammys, with the country last achieving success at the awards in 2012 via pop singer Gotye.
He is just the thirteenth Australian to earn the honour in the ceremony's 59-year history, and the first to win the Dance/Electronic category.
The Bee Gees, Olivia Newton-John, and Keith Urban are the most successful down under winners, each having four gongs to their name.
Welcome to the club: He is just the thirteenth Australian to win a Grammy in its 59-year history, and the first to take top honours in the Dance/Electronic category
The shortlist: The Bee Gees, Olivia Newton-John, and Keith Urban are the most successful down under winners, each having four gongs to their name
'Wow. This is totally insane,' the musician said at the ceremony in Los Angeles.
'I'm really proud to be here representing Australia and Australian music at the Grammys on this stage right now.'
Fellow-Aussies Sia, Keith Urban,Hillsong and Tim Davies had less success trying to add to the down under winners list earlier in the night, losing their categories to international competitors.
The award ceremony is split into two halves, with the three hour premiere event - at which Flume won his award - taking place before the major awards are announced from 12pm AEDT on Monday.
No luck: Fellow-Aussies Sia, Keith Urban (pictured),Hillsong and Tim Davies had less success trying to add to the down under winners list earlier in the night, losing their categories to international competitors
The main event: The award ceremony is split into two halves, with the three hour premiere event - at which Flume won his award - taking place before the major awards are announced from 12pm AEDT on Monday
